reviewText:
Lamia Must Die. . .Eventually. . . Just as soon as I stop dying.

Lamia Must Die is a game of adventure wherein you are not just one person but rather four people. You can change two of your party members and their styles are definitely unique. You adventure into a dungeon and skip all the trash tier monsters completely. The only game play is a big epic boss battle.

Graphics and Art

The graphics are not that good, but it's excuseable. This game runs mainly on artwork and pictures anyway and it's played through various GUI's, which all look and feel rather fluid and work well. The artwork itself is rather nice and sometimes kind of mediocre, though certainly better than I could care to draw. I'm not completely convinced that some of the pictures of the characters drawn were drawn by the creators of the game or anyone they hired. I don't think they were commissions and rather just something free. If they were drawn by the creators then I ask why there is no consistency in the art work. Some of it looks great while others look like it was drawn by a complete ametuer who had way too much interest in ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. I of course refer primarily to Lamia.

Story and Characters

The story is pretty alright. I give it a 6/10. Basically, there is a snake-lady (Naga?) monster attacking the village and eating their children. Many people have tried to slay this foul, big ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•d beast but all of the soldiers were eaten. They probably couldn't tear their eyes away from her ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. So now you and your vagabond party of adventurers/heroes/whatever-the-f*cks embark on a perilous journey to which you get little to no part in as far as interaction goes to venture into Lamia's cave and slay the bodacious reptilian babe. A bit sexist, if you ask me. No one's asking me so now we continue. It gives a campfire scene and talks about what they're going to do and how they're going to get to Lamia. This kind of bugs me because You" say that it's not as easy as just getting to the big bad monster
date: but it skips any gameplay that could have happened anyway. You're treated to a dialogue between yourself(s) and Lamia to which you learn a little more about her and then combat is engaged in. Overall
recommended: it's a fairly "meh" storyline.\n\nWhat I do like is the characters. They all have their reasons for being there
hoursPlayed: whether that be royal responsibility or just straight up revenge. They have different personalities and lives
voteText: as you would be able to see if you beat the game. The outro for each character is different depending on if they died or not. Try and find them all! I found myself at least a little bit drawn into their characters and those characters' lives

despite how little I'm told about them and how little exposure I get.

Sound and Music

The sounds are what you'd expect from a game like this. For the most part

votesFunny: most of the women don't seem to be so gifted and they seem to be trying a bit too hard to sound Fantasy-esque and it just doesn't end up working for them
commentsCount: though I wouldn't say they're terrible. Just average at best.\n\nThe music
column16: while I'm unsure if it's stock music or composed music

was fitting to the theme and sounded good. I didn't find myself getting bored of it at all. That being said I've only played about an hour and a half so far.

Gameplay

The gameplay consists of nothing other than a big

reviewText:
This is my review of this lovely little game put into points.

Great voice acting
The story is generic
The gameplay is fun

Otherwise worth a try since it's a totally free game!

reviewText:
A great game, considering what it is advertising.

The voice acting is great, and it gives personality to each character.
The story is simple and clear, nothing much to it. The endings are as good.

The fight is not that hard, really. It could be a bit more difficult.
There are also a few errors, but nothing that prevents gameplay.

Overall, I can't wait for both the prequel and the sequel for this short entry!
voteText: 15 of 19 people (79%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Exactly what it says on the tin. 20 minutes of JRPG from start to end credits. Some setup, some voiced dialogue (Charming amateur work.), some nice art, and one boss fight. It's all quite easy.

Just turn off active time battle. You don't know these characters so you'll have to check their skills.

You can change two party members, so you might want to replay to see what different plot there is.

Still, the whole thing is incredibly trivial. A lot of effort went into the art, voice work, etc, and everything is certainly workmanlike, but there's nothing all that interesting here. Fun enough for a freebie though.

In reflection, though, I think that is actually something profound. Look how rare it is for a game to have the monster ACTUALLY BE A MONSTER that must die. How rare it is for the heroes to actually save the day from a monster. There's no twist where you were the monster all along. No stupid navel gazing about two so gray so grimdark factions and having to pick blah blah.

When you get down to that, a game that promises heroes slaying a monster and saving the day and delivers exactly that... that is kinda rare these days, isn't it?

reviewText:
I really like the idea of 150+ hours of gameplay being compressed down to a single boss fight. But you're at a significant disadvantage from the start by not knowing the characters and skills. After a few tries though the battle is pretty straight forward. It took me 3 tries to beat Lamia and I have to admit I was a little disappointed that she didn't have multiple forms.

Some cons: I hate the button input sequences for the spells; I was using a controller and had to keep switching back and forth between that and my keyboard. It's also pretty devestating when you miss a input and waste your turn. I also experienced a significant amount of slow down even with the lower resolution. I have a pretty powerful setup so I know that wasn't what the problem is. My last nitpick is that I wish the meters and status effects for the characters where displayed more clearly and the turn reticle/circle thing was bigger.

Definitely worth a try if you're an old school rpg veteran, I mean you have nothing to lose (except time I guess) because it's free. I hope there's a sequel.

reviewText:
Quite the interesting game, multiple endings depending on which party members die or live throgh the fight, but the Blitz system was HORRIBLE, first of all, there should be a practise option in the menu for such things, secondly, the timer is equally short depending on if its a short simple sequences, as the most common one was, left, up, down left, Z, or a more complicated one, left, up, down, left, up, left, down, left, Z, X, D.

Five seconds is not enough, unless you are used to mashing in such combinations from perhaps 10 hours of gameplay.

This reminds me of the game Legend of the Dragoon, a old PS1 game where you have to mash X, O, Square or Triangle to preform timed combos, in the begining the combos are easy, but as you progress into the game, they get VERY hard and even add counters into the combo which you must recognize and react too.

This system is easy to learn, because you spend the entire game mastering them, but in this short game, where a fight lasts up to 15 minutes, and the blitz sequences are few between normal attacks, you hardly have enough time to master it, also.. the minimalistic damage on support chars is cringe worthy, they are more like meat shields then actual allies.

Overall, a good short multi-ending game, but poorly executed in terms of its mechanics.

My suggestion; Add a training option for blitz, and beef up the support char's damage a small bit.

You can't rely on the paladin's attack's chipping away at the Lamia's life.

reviewText:
The game is quite short, about 10-15 minutes, depending on how you strategize against Lamia, the one and only battle of the game. While I beat it on my first try, I'm sure others will try once or twice depending on how you go about the battle.

I understand that this was originally a standalone game, so I can see why you'd want to focus mostly on the boss battle itself. The battle system itself was definitely the star of the game, seeing as how it was more active than turn-based, which required more strategy and quick-thinking on the players' part. I did like the fact that you could choose different party members, for a different type of experience and ending depending on who you chose.

The voice acting, while it was nice, did feel a bit hammy and even forced on some lines. The characters themselves also would be nice to have some improvement on - while they had their own little backstory and endings, they did feel a bit generic. Perhaps some characterization work could be worked into the main battle itself?

Overall, a short, but good and potential-worthy game.

reviewText:
My full review can be found here.[www.the-backlog.net]

Lamia Must Die is a short and sweet game about killing the Lamia that has been terroring the citizens. You must assemble your team and then face down with her. That's all Lamia Must die is - cutscenes and her boss fight. Considering it's free, that's plenty for me.

After you choose your team from a couple options for your Paladin and ranged damage, you're given some brief cutscenes. After those you're thrust into the battle with the Lamia. She's not easy and will require quite a bit of strategy to actually take down. I definitely enjoyed how much she made me think, and how much I struggled to make it through even on Wait mode. The ending with all four heroes surviving was worth the struggle at least.

Don't go into Lamia Must Die expecting some award winning story. Do expect a boss fight that will keep you on your toes and thinking to figure out the best strategies. I do wish that there was an option to enter the menu at some point to adjust settings other than at the very beginning after you choose new game, but ah well. For the price of free, you may as well give Lamia Must Die a try, as long as you don't expect some big story out of it. And hey, it even has voice acting!

reviewText:
Would I recommend this game? No, I wouldn't, but that isn't because it's bad, it's because it's flawed, which you may see as the same thing, but I believe they're different. A bad game is a game with enough mistakes made to make one not want to play it at all. A flawed game is one that has mistakes, but small mistakes that are few. I think this is the latter.

So, the first flaw in this game, and probably the first you'll experience, would be the voice acting. Although you can turn it off from the options at the start, I played with it on, simply to see just what it's like. It was... Interesting. For those of you that have played Castlevania: SotN, you would know of the semi-cheesy lines between Richter (I think that's his first name) Belmont and Dracula. The voice acting in the game is a bit like that, just without the awesome gothic feel and the emotion. (And in my opinion, this is a little worse than said voice acting.)

The second I came across was the lack of character depth, as well as the general script. It's just TOO cheesy. Everyone's seen the Vengeful Vigilante stereotype before, and the female protagonist I used OOZED Righteous Warrior. *COUGHCOUGHRichterBelmontCOUGH* Not to mention, the origin of this group isn't told, or at least from up to where I got, which leads into my next point:

This feels like a tech demo. There's really no depth to the combat system, just another Final Fantasy style RPG. Also, why on Earth would you start us off at the END of their journey? That's like driving to the top of a mountain and walking down; unless you're doing that for some sort of activity, it's pointless and will only hinder you, the same as dropping people off at the end of the story and telling them to walk from there only works if you're doing something special with that.

Although I just listed a bunch of flaws in this game, it's actually not THAT bad. I'm a perfectionist when it comes to RPGs, so I may be being a little harsh, but even so, I can still recognise this game's potential, or at least, the potential of the developer. Iron out a few little kinks and you'll be well on your way with this.

reviewText: Why would you instantly throw the players into a battle with the boss immediately not knowing any of their specials or magic against an enemy with extreme damage and health? Instantly after getting into the fight all of your characters get their health lowered by 33%, about a quarter of the way into the fight the boss spawns two minions that require more than five turns to defeat each. You are turning a majority of your audience away if you are instantly going to throw them into something like this...\n\nNow let me get into the bugs that I have experienced. Immediately after starting the game I readjusted the resolution, and turned off the voice acting because that is not my cup of tea. Around two dialogue boxes are still voiced for some odd reason along with the characters voices in-fight as well. I restarted the game then went back into the fight, the game not being the resolution I had selected before, every image was resized to what I believe to be the previous resolution image size. I couldn't see Lamia and all of the characters were large and half not on the screen. Also, there is a cinematic scene in the beginning of what looks to be a plane of grass, the thing is that when you go into a larger resolution the image is not large enough and begins repeating on both top and bottom of the game.

reviewText:
Honestly I am kinda disappointed. I mean the boss fight itself wasn't very balanced.  Once I had Eric attack he dealt 1200 damage with a boost from the Priest. None of the other heros could deal more then 200 with the same boost. After I realized this I just had them heal with potions or the priests magic while I make the paladin murder the Lamia and then the thralls. After I got the ending where they all go off on an adventure we will never see I decided to do it this time but with everyone but the paladin dying.

It was kinda funny how the paladin didn't even show up to mourn any of the dead people, simply just going of on his adventure of saving the world, not even mentioning how they died.

Also no alternate ending where you can save the lamia, even if its a bit cliche.

Voice acting was a nice touch I guess, but the boss fight was lame mate, and in the end only the paladin dealt any real damage, regardless of who I choose for the 4th fighter. Hell I would had even taken a second or final form boss fight or something.

But I did dabble a bit with RPG Maker myself and I know how annoying it is to set up the fights to be balanced. I only wish this had more substance.

reviewText: Anyone who has ever driven long distances knows that a map helps alot. That's what identifying vision and goals is like. It shows you where you need to go to get to where you're going. The major problem with this is that your vision has to be less specific the further you plan ahead. The more specific you are the more often you will have to change your vision. Making your vision broad allows you to hammer out the fine details when it comes closer to that time. It also helps to stay motivated. It is considerably demoralizing to have this elaborate plan worked out only to have to throw it away over and over because little things would throw it all out of whack.

reviewText: The game is really short. Not many choices as to where the story goes. Overall I didn't enjoy it, it really could have been better. An RPG maker game shouldn't use voice acting, leave room for imagination. Only one battle in the whole game, and it wasn't that great. It has potential but there should have been much more work put into it. When I look to play a RPG maker game, I want a long story with characters I can get attached to. This does not have that, it also lacks in character depth. To the creator of this game, you have potential but make it longer. Also make it more involving, we don't see what led up to them getting there. We didn't have a story just a short battle.

reviewText:
As much as I love RPG, this one makes the list but with one exception: Killing Lamia

I'll be honest that the voice-acting in this game is truly amazing, so is the gameplay as it has that Final Fantasy feeling for anyone that played Final Fantasy (FF for short).

But, as I said before, the exception is about Lamia, the monster that you need to kill in order to progress through the game but that won't be easy as she has 7777 HP and some trolling attacks that blinds your party, make your party members insane (i.e. hitting each other), poison them and she hits you hard as she deals 100 or more damage to you.

Also, if you think about dying (as I did multiple times) is going to progress through the game as you think that the fallen heroes will somehow get resurrected, you're wrong! It just gives you a small narration about the town being devoured by Lamia and about her killing everything and it takes you back to the main menu.

Am I doing something wrong? I just don't seem to understand why it puts you with a boss fight when you start the game.

reviewText:
This game was fun and EXTREMELY SHORT!!!!
I beat it in only 6 minutes! I'm not lying!
The one boss in this game who is also the Final boss is hard as hell..... on Active gameplay, But if you switch the gameplay to Turn based, The game changes! The boss becomes so easy to defeat because she rarely have time to attack. You and your party just keeps taking her turns for attacking. After a while of stealing the Boss's turns, You're gonna feel sorry for her!

The best way to describe this game is that, It's a Jrpg that had it's free roam, The beginning and middle of it's story stripped from it! All that's left of the game is the Final battle and ending.

Now if this game's developers were charging money for Lamia Must Die" Then I would NEVER recommend it! But this game is free and I did have some enjoyment with it! I really like the characters. I wish the developers put more time in to giving them all backstory and fleshing them out more
recommended: I think this is a interesting game for what it is and is definitely worth a download."

reviewText:
As a freebie, I would recommend giving this game an honest try.  I like the concept: Skipping the typical RPG grind and going straight to the endgame with all of your items and powers in tow.  The game gives enough of a narrative prior to the battle to at least become interested in the overall story.

Where I find fault with the game is with the presentation.  I have two main gripes.  First, the UI elements at the bottom which represent your party are far too small to suit me.  I found it a little hard to tell exactly what my party's status was at times as it was also hard to determine what, if any, status effects they were suffering.  This didn't become an issue until later in the fight because I found a protection spell and cast it early, but it made managing party health a little more troublesome than it should have been.  Likewise, I couldn't tell if status effects I tried to cast on Lamia were working; I'm not sure if the text/graphics were too small or if they may have been covered by her health bar.  I kind of just had to go with it.

Control schemes are the other big issue.  The game seems to demand that you play with the keyboard.  I may have just not known how to find the option, but I was unable to either view or reconfigure the controller inputs for my game pad (this is another game where keyboard-to-controller profiling software may come in handy).  While you can play with a controller, the inputs for additional spell effects cannot be effectively completed since the game displays the keyboard input it expects without translating it to a controller.  This meant that I could not complete these sequences, costing me additional damage and artificially extending the battle.

None of this necessarily means the game isn't fun to play, but it shows a lack of polish.  The concept itself is sound, and the actual battle is interesting.  A nice touch is that you can choose from either a standard JRPG turn-based battle system, or a form of Active-Time Battle like you might see in a Final Fantasy title.  You also get a respectably long ending sequence after the battle is won.  It took me just under half an hour for a complete, first-time playthrough, and I managed a completely deathless playthrough as well (meaning that I not only didn't lose my party, I never lost a fighter in battle).  RPG veterans shouldn't have trouble navigating the battle; if you're a newcomer, it's not unreasonable to fail a few times, but this is actually a good beginner's RPG to get used to the ideas of resource management, status protection, and healing.

So the answer is yes, I recommend this game, moreso because it is a free game.  Despite issues with the presentation and controls, it's still relatively fun for the half hour it lasts.  I believe that a future update can eliminate the issues it still has.  I hope that the developers learn from this and put together something similar that's a little more refined in the future, because I think this type of concept has legs.  I think it's a respectable first attempt for what it is trying to accomplish.

6.0 out of 10

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Product received for free

Hampered by its length and poor design decisions. The story is rushed in the beginning to get to the touted battle with Lamia and it leads to you learning the characters and the battle system simultaneously.  The game is also partially optimized for each resolution option instead of being fully optimized for any of them.  The opening looks fine on a lower resolution, but the background and character pictures don't fit correctly into the larger ones.  The battle is only fully viewable on a higher resolution, though.  Also, the full sized character models don't really match the partial ones and some of the full sized models are somewhat grotesque.

One positive is the character selection in the beginning.  The story reaches where the main character arrives and when you choose between Janet and Eric it describes their benefits and drawbacks as part of the story.  I almost recommended this game solely for this feature, i think this is a really neat way to do this and if you're interested in RPG games and have a minute you should look at the beginning, but in the end it's just too bad to recommend for any reason.
